newsitem.title: INDIA: India call money ends down, securities prices ease.
newsitem.headline: India call money ends down, securities prices ease.

text.p: Indian call money ended Friday at 4.75 percent, down from opening levels of 5.25-5.75 percent on reduced demand, dealers said.
They said rates dropped from opening levels as there was borrower resistance at higher levels.
"The market continues to be easy," said a dealer at a state-run bank. "It is difficult to see call money rise much above the repos rate of 5.0 percent."
The Reserve Bank of India has maintained a rate of 5.0 percent at its repo auctions since the first week of February.
Dealers said prices of government securities were largely down in moderate trade on profit-taking by banks.
They said traded volumes fell to 1.65 billion rupees on Friday from Thursday's 2.88 billion.
Dealers said trades were less as bankers had become slightly apprehensive over liquidity.
"When call opened higher today, some banks feared that call money would tighten," said a foreign bank dealer.
"Action was concentrated in treasury bills and in securities with maturities up to 2002," he said.
The 13.50 percent 1998 traded on Friday at 103.10 rupees against 103.15, the 12 percent 1999 at 100.08 against 100.09 and the zero-coupon bond 1999 at 80.14 against 80.13, dealers said.
The 13.55 percent 2001 slipped to 101.92 from 101.95 while the 13.82 percent 2002 dropped to 101.88 from 101.94, they said.
Dealers said treasury bills maturing in June yielded 8.36 percent, July bills 9.82, August bills 9.92 and September bills 10.02 percent.
There were no trades in commercial paper or certificates of deposit, they said.
